description: Mid-15th century, from Latin obduratus (“hardened”), form of obdūrō (“harden”), from ob- (“against”) + dūrō (“harden, render hard”), from durus (“hard”). Compare durable, endure.

adjectives.description: obdurate (comparative more obdurate, superlative most obdurate)

entries.meaning: Stubbornly persistent, generally in wrongdoing; refusing to reform or repent.

examples: The past is obdurate for the same reason a turtle's shell is obdurate: because the living flesh inside is tender and defenseless.

verbs.description: obdurate (third-person singular simple present obdurates, present participle obdurating, simple past and past participle obdurated)
